Simon Wardley’s Post

Simon Wardley
1y Edited
  • Report this post

When people say "China's DeepSeek Bombshell" - https://lnkd.in/eUnYsTvq what they really mean is China's obvious and well signalled move towards open source AI - https://lnkd.in/eJ9kQ-Dc - and this is only the beginning i.e. not there yet. It is unfortunate the West continues to pursue a dual path of new theocracies under AI - https://lnkd.in/exJVmNvD - and the creation of Elysium. We had several opportunities to adapt and change course. I will admit to my own bias here, I've never been keen on the idea of crypto bro feudal lords aka the rise of the petulant man child. Hence I'm glad that China remains committed to common prosperity and the creation of that vision of a Star Trek Federation. In that sense I suppose it's useful that China's strategic gameplay far exceeds anything that Western business leaders can muster. It's never over though. France demonstrates some good cheer and strategic wit by continuing to push with Mistral AI. In the UK, in 2010, I was involved in trying to help Gov become more open, to adopt new ways of thinking - https://lnkd.in/e7-u8APN - and we had some small successes and that still continues today which is encouraging. Even in the gloom, there are always sparks of creativity and clear thinking such as the marvellous Boiling Frogs paper by GCHQ https://lnkd.in/e5P_fTYN. It's never over because good people continue to fight the fight to make society a better place. Our future in the West doesn't have to be the super wealthy in Bugatti starships whilst the many live in abject poverty fighting over crumbs. However, back to the subject of China. In 2015 when I presented my China vs USA research in Washington (the poorly named "Clash of the Titans" report), I explained how through a combination of techniques from understanding supply chains to gameplay to use of mixed economic models (see map below) that China would out-innovate and outpace the US across a huge range of industries. I argued that we needed to become more strategic, more open and focus on common prosperity. I was met with guffaws, dismissal and senior execs declaring that "Silicon Valley would out innovate China" - it was naked racism mixed with nationalistic viewpoints, hubris and an overdose of greed. I'm not convinced much has changed in the last decade. It's a shame. The US has massive problems heading its way including the disaster that will become bitcoin - https://lnkd.in/egjPqd8b. The failure to adapt the "Washington" economic model to something more contextual will also not serve it well. This division will become blindingly obvious over the next decade with China leading the world not only in economic and technological landscapes but also in the social and political ones. This is not a "Trump" thing, this started long before him. He is a symptom not a cause nor a cure. Well, to be more accurate, I have no reason to believe he is a cure. I do hope we adapt with grace in the West. Alas "grace" and "petulant man child" don't mix well.

Simon Wardley 1y
  • Report this comment

What is happening is a well signalled move "towards" open source AI, however it's not there yet. The real payload happens when China open sources the training data. At which point the US AI scene could be in real trouble. I'm fairly convinced that a lot of US based AI companies don't even know what training data they've actually used, it hasn't been recorded effectively. I know of one major system where that's the case. China has already indicated it will use (and is building) blacklists for training data. If US companies can't provide provenance then they'll be out of the game. What are enterprises going to use? An AI system with unknown provenance in training data that pretends to be open source with claims of "trust us" or an actual open source AI which includes open source training data that you can see and even run yourself? There is no open source AI without open source training data. Never was. Personally, I will enjoy listening to the twisted arguments that OSI will try and come up with for its mangled definition of Open Source AI (OSAID) when China will be able to clearly say "Open source should mean all the symbolic instructions are open sourced and that includes the training data"

Thorsten Speil 1y

A focus on common prosperity fits very well with what W. Deming already said with his New Economics in the 80s/90s. He had shown on a national scale 3 times that collaboration makes countries strong, not competition: the US war effort in WWII, then Japan, and then the US to some extent in the 80s/90s. Also fits very well with TOC thinking. Greed, disdain and distrust regularly wreck civilizations ... and it seems the western emphasis on individual "winning" through making others lose makes us very vulnerable to that trap.
